title: Macro Live, Yellen testimony
bodyHTML:
2:58 pm
CG

Greetings!

CG

Welcome to the Yellen tea-leaves-reading edish of Macro Live

CG

Matt and Cardiff coming at you live

2:59 pm
CG

Yellen about to kick off in just a minute

CG

Rabble, say hello as you join

MK

If you haven't read yet, here are the links to the testimony http://www.federal...ellen20160210a.htm and the longer Monetary Policy Report http://www.federal..._mprfullreport.pdf

3:00 pm
CG

Specifically, we're here today for the "Semiannual Monetary Policy Report to the Congress
Before the Committee on Financial Services, U.S. House of Representatives"

CG

we'll be keeping track of all the dumbest questions, which is the best reason to listen to these hearings, in addition to, you know, any monetary policy implications

CG

Our man Sam Fleming is live at the hearing, and sends along these notes:

3:01 pm
CG

The Fed Up protest movement is a big presence here this morning. As Mrs Yellen testifies on Capitol Hill she will be flanked by green-t-shirted protesters angry at the Fed's decision to raise rates in December and warning it not to pull the trigger again. Their motivation? A fear that higher rates will depress wage gains. Since the December financial turmoil around the world has given the Fed more reason for caution.

CG

Good to see the dovish flank represented

MK

Watch it here http://www.c-span..../?channel=c-span-3

3:03 pm
MK

Here is the better link https://financialservices.house.gov/

CG

hi nomad, hi bboc

MK

Currently listening to the opening statement from Hensarling, the head of the House Financial Services Committee

3:03 pm
CG

Hensarling speaking now

MK

He is citing data on weak median income growth

MK

"I will not use this hearing to criticize the Fed's decision to raise interest rates"

3:04 pm
MK

"I do feel compelled to demand that the Fed adopt a monetary policy course..." that follows a rule

CG

the fun stuff begins once these opening guys shut up

CG

citing Hayek -- drink!

3:05 pm
MK

CG, remember the last time this happened we got to hear a Congressman claim God wouldn't raise rates in the winter

CG

"unsustainable federal debt" -- drink!

MK

Opecmoney, C-span actually not the best source, go to the House website

3:06 pm
CG

I'm not gonna last longer than fifteen minutes at this rate

MK

Stay strong, stay strong

CG

on the other hand, i already won Fed bingo and Yellen hasn't even started talking yet

3:06 pm
MK

"central bankers...central planners"

CG

thanks for that bit of nonsensical pablum, chair Hensarling

MK

Oh now Maxine Waters starts talking

3:07 pm
MK

This might be even stranger

CG

Maxine Waters up now; opens by thanking Yellen for showing up (Yellen probably thinking "I didn't know bailing on this was an option!")

MK

"I'm just here so I don't get fined"

3:08 pm
MK

Waters is worried about impact of further rate hikes on "vulnerable populations". Also not a fan of IOER, which she says is "paying banks not to lend their reserves"

CG

Waters notes that inflation is running below target, wonders if further rate rises would be hasty. She actually sounds coherent thus far; must have a new speechwriter -- wait now she starts in on IOER which she doesn't understand SHE BLEW IT SHE WAS DOING SO WELL

CG

hello opecmoney, shadowbanker, concerned -- thanks for joining us!

3:12 pm
CG

Mulvaney making a case for scaling back Fed responsibility

CG

scale back all the way back to "long-term price stability"

MK

Interesting bit from the Monetary Policy Report is this chart on impact of dollar appreciation on inflation 1

3:13 pm
MK

https://twitter.com/M_C_Klein/status/697438030047637504/photo/1

MK

Actually interesting question about policy divergence between Fed and foreign CBs

CG

yes

3:14 pm
MK

Yellen starting

CG

Can follow along here, of course: http://www.federal...ellen20160210a.htm

CG

netprophet, indeed

3:18 pm
MK

Yellen gives a shoutout to purchases of cars and light trucks as particularly strong source of growth

MK

(For context, those purchases are extremely cyclical and if we were in a recession, you'd see vehicle sales collapse http://ftalphavill...ession-look-like/)

CG

truth

3:19 pm
CG

here's that link again, Matt (busted above): http://ftalphavill...cession-look-like/

CG

Yellen cites China's economic indicators

CG

BUT

3:21 pm
CG

https://twitter.com/CardiffGarcia/status/697176122468012033

CG

one for later

CG

anyways, back to Yellen

3:21 pm
CG

commentary thus far says that

CG

her statement is more dovish than overall Fed's current stance, more hawkish than market wants -- though that's about what you'd expect: that she would be both comforting but also opaque about what she might do in March

CG

as she is meant to be representing the entire Fed at the hearing

3:23 pm
CG

https://twitter.com/DuncanWeldon/status/697440415063142404

MK

From the box in the MPR on "Developments related to financial stability":

MK

"Vulnerabilities owing to leverage and maturity transformation in the financial sector remain low"

3:24 pm
CG

hit me!

CG

From US markets editor Robin Wigglesworth:

CG

https://twitter.com/RobinWigg/status/697440906014756864

3:25 pm
MK

Ah but according to Yellen this is all changes in the term premium cough *cough*

MK

"transitory" -- drink!

MK

Once again Yellen makes the point she wants to avoid rapid tightening in the future

3:26 pm
MK

Better to boil the frog slowly or something

MK

Another interesting bit from the MPR:

CG

erlkin, let's limit ourselves to snarking about the issues rather than appearances, please -- had to delete that

3:27 pm
MK

, the Board announced that it is seeking
public comment on its proposed framework for
setting the Countercyclical Capital Buffer (CCyB)
and voted to affirm the CCyB amount at the current
level of 0 percent—consistent with the continued
moderate level of financial vulnerabilities.3
The buffer is a macroprudential tool that can be used
to increase the resilience of the financial system by
raising capital requirements on internationally active
banking organizations when there is an elevated risk
of above-normal losses in the future. The CCyB would
then be available to help those banking organizations
absorb shocks associated with worsening credit
conditions, and it may also help moderate fluctuations
in the supply of credit.

MK

You'd think if we were in an expansion and Fed were worried about financial risks, the CCyB would be greater than zero

CG

mk, think the point is that you raise when there aren't financial worries, no?

3:30 pm
MK

If countercyclical, buffer should rise as assets become potentially overvalued, and fall when they become cheap

MK

(Whether this is a good idea I have no clue...)

CG

agree, anyways i'll be thrilled if she gets a question about that

3:30 pm
MK

Unless the Fed recently cut the CCyB because of concerns about losses on energy, abroad, etc

CG

Hensarling to begin the questioning, which ensures an appropriate level of hostility and ignorance to get things going

MK

Hensarling wants the Fed to make its "reaction function" more transparent to facilitate the decisions of "working families"

3:32 pm
CG

now reading from their earlier letters to each other

MK

mutant_dog, I think so

MK

Hensarling citing some big names in support of his policy -- Lars Hansen, Robert Lucas, Jerry Jordan, Ed Prescott

3:33 pm
CG

oh my god, it's like an Olympic roster of Freshwater economists. Please, for the love all that is holy, get to the point

CG

DUDE ENOUGH WITH THE NAMES

MK

Boskin is an interesting person to cite. He's the guy who helped change the way inflation is measured, thereby leading to Mr Shadowstats

3:35 pm
MK

The underlying tension between Hensarling et al's position and Yellen et al's position is that people at the Fed don't want to admit they're (always) winging it because central banking is hard

MK

(IMHO)

CG

Yeah, but oh my god, Hensarling cautioning Yellen against apocalyptic and hyperbolic language. I can't, I just can't -- Matt, if I pass out, just leave me there

3:37 pm
CG

MK, I think the underlying tension is that Hensarling et al want Yellen and the Fed to admit that central banking is hard and that they should be doing it the way Hensarling et al want her to do it, because apparently it's hard for her but not for them. You're giving them too much credit, I think

CG

Maxine Waters up

MK

To clarify, I think Hensarling doesn't agree (or know?) monetary policy is as hard as Yellen et al think, but Yellen et al are reluctant to admit it, hence silly arguments about "independence"

3:38 pm
MK

Waters wants to know about paying IOER

CG

Question about alternative ways to raise rates without paying "subsidies" to banks via IOER

MK

"alternative approaches"

3:39 pm
MK

Yellen notes IOER goes back 10 years

MK

and had been discussed even before then

MK

after all, foreigners do it

3:40 pm
CG

Yellen to now give a mechanical explanation of why the Fed pays IOER that will be totally correct and sail over the committees head, maybe with some exceptions. But it's a fair issue to raise in this context, I'll admit

MK

Interruption!

MK

"To regain control over short term interest rates we would need to shrink our portfolio"

3:41 pm
MK

"Shrink in a gradual and predictable way"

MK

Waters asking if Congress could remove ability to pay IOER

CG

she's explaining that the higher rates get passed through to depositors/savers, a point that always gets missed when people try to make the "IOER is a giveaway to banks" argument

3:43 pm
MK

Yellen talking about Fed distribution of "profits" to Treasury

MK

Now the Vice-Chairman of the House Finserv committee

MK

Yellen is incredulous about question regarding spread between IOER and Fed Funds

3:44 pm
MK

"has it ever been below??"

CG

Oh my god Mulvaney, YOU CAN LOOK THIS STUFF UP

MK

(subtext, AYFKM?)

3:44 pm
CG

what an idiotic question

CG

I'm gonna have a stroke

MK

"Let's move then to a different discussion..."

3:45 pm
MK

deadcat

CG

Now he's going to confuse a rules-based approach to monetary policy with a binding mechanism

MK

I'm a big believer in democratic accountability over central banks but it would be nice if the people directly charged with that responsibility were better at their jobs

3:46 pm
CG

What the hell was all that about?

CG

Yellen crushed that interruption

MK

From Wikipedia:

3:48 pm
MK

Mulvaney attended Georgetown University where he majored in International Economics, Commerce and Finance. At Georgetown, he was an Honors Scholar, the highest level of academic achievement awarded to members of the Georgetown School of Foreign Service, and ultimately graduated with honors in 1989.

CG

A fellow Georgetown grad -- that's the problem right there. We're a bunch of hooligans. But you don't see me sitting on any important committees

CG

New to this, we just rock and roll around here. Make incisive commentary, ask questions, and keep snark within respectable boundaries

3:49 pm
CG

(and welcome)

CG

Moore now

MK

Question about smaller banks

3:51 pm
MK

Interesting to see a Democrat arguing about "regulatory burden" on community banks

MK

This is a standard complaint from the American Bankers Association

MK

Yellen explaining how basically all of Basel III has nothing to do with community banks

3:52 pm
CG

Dems often have an idyllic view of community banks

MK

OOH!

CG

which is fine in the sense that they're not systemically threatening, so I don't have a problem with this question, but in a macroeconomic context it isn't hugely important

3:53 pm
MK

Good question about why no one has gone to jail for the crisis

MK

"I agree with you. Individuals guilty of wrongdoing should not escape penalities"

CG

negative rates question!

3:55 pm
MK

Negative rates legal authority question!

MK

context is a memo where staffers said "maybe not"

MK

here's the original memo http://www.federal...ER.memo.public.pdf

3:56 pm
CG

last considered in 2010

CG

basically, the answer is "I don't know yet"

MK

"remains a question we would need to investigate more carefully"

3:56 pm
MK

Policy Tensor: nobody knows for sure

MK

"In the spirit of prudent planning we always try to look at what options are available to us"

CG

In normal-person speak, \_(ツ)_/¯

3:57 pm
MK

"I am not aware of anything that would prevent us from doing it but we have not fully investigated the legal issues"

CG

they should get on this!

CG

McHenry knocked it out with that question

3:58 pm
MK

Yes, good for him

MK

Netprophet: interesting idea, but then we'd have to figure out who determines what constitutes an "asinine question"

MK

Question about "turmoil in global markets"

4:01 pm
CG

this one could go either way. the suspense is killing me

MK

I would be curious to know what Yellen thinks about yields

MK

"Has this changed your view about appropriate pace of hikes?"

4:01 pm
MK

another good question

MK

Yellen blames uncertainties on Chinese FX policy and oil

MK

"We have not seen shifts that seem significant enough to drive these sharp moves"

4:02 pm
MK

"Increased fears of recession risk"

MK

"Not yet seen a sharp dropoff in growth, either globally or in the US"

MK

"Financial conditions have become less supportive to growth"

4:03 pm
MK

"Monetary policy is not on a preset course"

MK

Follow-up question: "what would it take for you to consider cutting rates again?"

CG

good Q

4:04 pm
CG

which she'll definitely not answer

MK

"Let's remember the labor market is continuing to perform well"

CG

doesn't believe FOMC in a situation where they'll cut rates

4:04 pm
MK

(It's a lagging indicator, though...)

CG

"many of the factors holding inflation are transitory"

MK

Howdy

4:04 pm
MK

deadcat

CG

we should get a market update

CG

Rabble, help us out

4:05 pm
MK

Blue-Light: the cynic in me would say China gets the blame because it's easier

MK

Breakeven question!

CG

S&P up .85% on the day

4:06 pm
CG

anybody have a 10year quote for us?

MK

Erlkin, wow

MK

I'm old enough to remember when people were worried about rising rates

4:07 pm
MK

Next question about 13(3)

MK

That's about emergency lending, which was tightened up in Dodd-Frank

MK

Fed didn't like what was in Dodd-Frank and wrote rules giving it a lot of discretion to lend in emergencies

4:09 pm
MK

He's comparing the Fed's approach to 13(3) versus what it did in the Volcker Rule

MK

actually not a terrible question

MK

He's highlighting the Fed's preference for maximum flexibility to do what it wants, against the rules it's imposed on banks etc

4:11 pm
MK

Blue-Light: literally, no, but in practice, they have flexibility to write rules which may undermine the spirit

CG

Can't give a specific answer -- actually does depend on the circumstances -- but not a bad idea about the process for calculating the rate

MK

Blue-Light, the risk with this strategy is then Congress yells at you and makes new rules

4:11 pm
MK

Citing Fischer's speech from today is a solid move, for Garrett

CG

true

MK

This is the speech http://www.federal...scher20160210a.htm

4:12 pm
MK

Yellen is getting frustrated by this, losing her cool

MK

"We cannot lend to an insolvent borrower"

CG

"Can only put in place broad-based program" -- would be good to know how to determine when line from solvent to insolvent is crossed, though

4:13 pm
MK

The core issue here is that there is no good way to run a lender of last resort without either giving away free money or hurting legit businesses

MK

For those who care, I had some thoughts about LoLR issues when it turned out there were debates about Lehman's solvency at the time http://ftalphavill...ts-the-difference/

CG

(not always obvious given possibility of high recovery values post-crisis)

4:15 pm
MK

Right, in the heat of the moment you can't know

CG

what's this question about, then?

CG

the current one, I mean

4:15 pm
CG

missed it

MK

Yellen now answering a question about differences in employment among different demographics

CG

ah

4:16 pm
MK

Actually fits with something Kocherlakota wrote recently on his blog, which, I can't find right now

MK

Question about labor participation rate

MK

Here's the Kocherlakota piece I was thinking of https://sites.goog...-on-policy/1-18-16

4:18 pm
MK

"Wouldn't surprise me if wage trends weren't part of the reason for [falling LFPR among men]"

CG

got a quote from Kocherlakota you can post here?

MK

Kocherlakota:

4:18 pm
MK

here is one key source of economic difference in American life that is likely underemphasized in FOMC deliberations: race. Let’s look, for example, at the most recently released transcripts for FOMC meetings, which cover the year 2010 (my first full year on the Committee). It was a challenging year for the US economy as a whole, as the unemployment rate was above 9 1/4% in every month. But it was especially challenging for African-Americans: In every month of 2010, the unemployment rate among African-Americans was at least 15 1/2%. I did a search of the hundreds of pages of the meeting transcripts. Based on that search, my conclusion is that there was no reference in the meetings to labor market conditions among African-Americans (or Black Americans).

CG

ta

CG

Neugebaur saying economy still not great, cites a bunch of figures, including number of people on SNAP, people who bailed on the labour market, etc

4:21 pm
MK

He's blaming regulations that "increase the cost of capital" for weakness

MK

Tell me again the price/sales ratio of tech unicorns again?

MK

Pro-tip: don't cite Europeans for optimal bank capital regulation

4:24 pm
CG

lol

CG

Sherman

MK

I still don't know what the question is about

4:25 pm
MK

He's talking about how Trump and Sanders won in NH

MK

roddy1234: yes, well aware of IFRS vs GAAP standards on netting

CG

what is happening with this question

4:26 pm
MK

I still don't know what the question is

MK

Here it is:

CG

I this guy about to run for President?

4:26 pm
CG

someone should tell him it's a crowded field

CG

asking about Financial Stability Oversight Committee

MK

Oh I think it's about personal responsibility for executives for problems at banks

4:27 pm
MK

using FSOC to break up TBTF banks

CG

wants Janet Yellen to break up the banks

MK

heck of an opener

4:28 pm
MK

Policy Tensor: they could raise G-SIB fee high enough to encourage it, but yeah...

CG

then throws up his hands in existential resignation, recognising that life will be one damn thing after another

MK

"I need to move onto another question"

4:28 pm
CG

Hey bro, if you need to "move onto another question", maybe don't make big speeches before each one

MK

Question about regional Fed bank governance

MK

For some interesting context, there was a big debate about changing how regional bank heads were appointed in the mid-1990s, Greenspan killed it

4:29 pm
CG

Then doesn't let her respond. That was crap from Sherman

MK

Because regional banks give Fed lots of influence on local politics because of contacts with business leaders

MK

(also they get good intelligence about local conditions)

4:30 pm
MK

Current question is what Fed could do if we have another downturn

CG

important

MK

"Most importantly, the path of short-term interest rates"

4:30 pm
MK

egads

MK

your best move is to stop hiking?

CG

she's answering a question he didn't ask

4:31 pm
MK

Gonna go out on a limb and say the problem isn't long rates are too high

CG

I wonder if she's filibustering so that she doesn't have to say "MOAR QE"

MK

she can't really say negative rates given the earlier question

4:32 pm
CG

yep

MK

moving short rates is really more understandable way to manipulate the economy than QE?

MK

for the average person?

4:32 pm
MK

I mean, maybe

MK

Now the question is about corporate tax inversion

MK

If she responds by talking about how high US corp tax keeps down the dollar and thereby boosts competitiveness of exports I'd be impressed

4:35 pm
MK

"We routinely look at the stance of fiscal policy"

CG

weird question about whether she has a model for changing monetary policy in response to a change in corporate tax rates?

CG

didn't quite follow

4:35 pm
CG

Meeks up now

MK

I think this question is if we're better off now than in 2007-8

MK

now he's asking about widening wealth disparity between whites and non-whites

4:37 pm
MK

which was a nasty consequence of housing credit bubble

CG

question about implementing CRA to compel large banks to make loans in devastated communities

MK

"We take our enforcement and evaluation of banks' CRA performance very seriously"

4:40 pm
CG

hitting point of diminishing marginal returns, frankly

MK

Current speaker was a former reality star on the Real World

CG

Duffy asking question about Fannie and Freddie

4:41 pm
MK

question is about Fannie and Freddie, and it's based on deep misunderstanding of what's happened

MK

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_Duffy

CG

"Fannie and Freddie weren't touched at all" -- um, other than being nationalised?

4:42 pm
MK

In 1997, Duffy appeared on The Real World: Boston, the sixth season of the MTV reality television show, and on Road Rules: All Stars in 1998, where he met his future wife Rachel. Duffy later appeared on Real World/Road Rules Challenge: Battle of the Seasons, which aired in 2002. Both appeared in a filmed segment on 2008's The Real World Awards Bash, while Duffy served as district attorney.

MK

I bet Fairholme and Ackman et al would find it funny to say GSEs "weren't touched"

CG

does he know fannie and freddie were placed into conservatorship and their profits are now remitted to treasury?

4:43 pm
MK

Now he's asking about Fed leaks

MK

(which is a legitimate question)

CG

yes indeed

4:45 pm
MK

I wish Duffy had led with this instead of the GSE question

CG

I don't want to like this dude, but this is a legit question

CG

I didn't follow that procedural issue

4:46 pm
CG

Hinojosa up now

MK

I'm not sure what the question is

CG

Questions about debt sustainability

4:50 pm
CG

question about Fed and inequality

CG

main contribution from Fed is to make sure labour market is performing well

CG

Stress test Q

4:52 pm
MK

question about negative rates in stress test

CG

yep

CG

"Bill Budley" would be a great name

4:53 pm
MK

lol

CG

5 more minutes

CG

Then we're cashing out, whether they finish on time or not

4:55 pm
CG

Yellen saying don't read too much into it, basically

CG

repeating question of Fed authority to lower rates to negative

CG

They really should have an answer to this question

4:56 pm
MK

"In light of European experience, we should look at it"

CG

no kidding!

MK

"Not just a question of legal authority, could the plumbing of the US handle it?"

4:56 pm
CG

Those are all good questions; they should start trying to answer them!

CG

Scott

MK

"I vehemently disagree with you when you say you can't target unemployment"

4:58 pm
CG

I don't think she said that. I think she said they can't target individual demographics

MK

"There is no other agency that has the mandate to deal with it [unemployment] than the Fed" -- Congressman

MK

Policy Tensor: Roger Ferguson was a Vice Chairman, now runs TIAA-CREF

5:02 pm
MK

He's highlighting real social problems, I'm not sure what he expects Yellen to say, though

CG

Scott making an impassioned plea for Fed to take into account the higher unemployment rate for young black Americans. Have to sympathize, but not sure what Fed can do beyond letting the economy run hot (which, it should be noted, the Fed is not doing)

MK

Honestly it shouldn't be that hard to get more diversity on the regional banks

5:03 pm
CG

Scott wants an African American to serve as regional Fed bank president

MK

No rule they have to be econ PhDs

MK

And even if they were

5:03 pm
CG

good point; I didn't know there had never been one

MK

Question about industry consolidation among community banks

MK

(Yellen gave a long answer with lots of acronyms)

5:08 pm
MK

Now we have a question about nominal value of US govt debt

CG

another question about national debt

CG

at current path, will continue to rising beyond 100% of GDP and then keep going; essential that Congress address long-run deficit issue, she says

5:09 pm
MK

"Rising national debt" sounds like such a downer, should instead talk about "growing supply of safe assets demanded by private sector"

CG

Green asking about African American unemployment, whether it was included in the statement

CG

Asks that she make her concerns more explicit

5:12 pm
CG

Says she's open to it

MK

I miss the days when people referred to it diminuitively as "Taylor's rule" rather than "The Taylor Rule"

CG

Taylor Rule; I'd say "drink!" but you guys are half in the bag by now

5:12 pm
CG

and someone needs to get work done this afternoon

CG

BornCynic, come on, no need for that; zapping

CG

Everyone, we love smart sarcasm and even snark around here, but commenting on someone's appearance or making ad hominem attacks on our colleagues won't be tolerated

5:15 pm
MK

Question now about custody banks

CG

BornCynic, thanks for clarifying. Easy to misinterpret comments on this platform; glad it's all good

CG

Question about custody banks. Okay folks, we've been here longer than anticipated, but Matt and I have other stuff to do today, so we're closing down

5:16 pm
CG

Thanks for joining!

CG

And we'll catch you here the next time, probably for the March FOMC meeting. Matt, closing thoughts?

MK

It seems like Yellen's message (and by extension, the views of the Fed as a whole) hasn't changed much since we heard from her in December. The two particularly interesting points, for me, were her reactions to the idea of negative rates and the stonewalling on the issue of leaks.

5:20 pm
MK

CG what were your takeaways?

CG

The answer to the question about negative rates was surprising and disappointing. Why isn't the Fed preparing for this possibility more actively? This has become one of the most prominent issues of 2016, and probably THE most important conceptual issue for global central banks.

CG

That the Fed hasn't even considered the possibility suggests they're not taking seriously the chances that growth will be slower than they expect, and I wish they would -- no matter whether you're optimistic or pessimistic about the near-term economic outlook.

5:23 pm
CG

Okay, I'm done. Thanks everybody, we're outttahere!

CG

DRINK AGAIN
